Use aluminum pan with 1/4 to 1/2 of water. Use a small grill grate lay on top of pan. Place whole bacon strips  on grill grate. Make sure bacon drippings will fall in pan,don't let hang over sides. Put in middle of oven on low broil. Don't cover. Keep bacon 8 to 10 inches from top heating element. Takes 20-30 minutes. May need to turn over at 15-20 minutes. Ovens and bacon brands cook differently. Will need to experiment. I can achieve soft crispy bacon everytime. Bacon fat falls in pan. Let cool down and fat will separate from water. Chicken cooks fabulous this way. 90-110 minutes legs,thighs,cornish hens. Also hamburgers. Takes practice with hamburger, cook time varies. All grease falls in water.

I almost always oven cook my bacon. You do need to flip them halfway through the cooking time, and you also need to pour off the rendered fat when you do the flip. Oven cooked bacon ... my experience for best results is to 1) place the tray of bacon into a "cold" oven and 2) cook at 350 degrees.  Results are a, for me, a tasty strip of flat bacon.  Using the "cold" oven and having the temperature rise with the bacon in the oven helps to render the bacon fat while cooking the meat.  Admittedly, 350 cooks longer than 400+, but, I feel it gives you more control over avoiding overcooking the bacon.

Here is my method: First, I retain ALL of my bacon grease in the fridge. When I make bacon, I melt all the used grease, so that it is about 1 to 2 inches deep in the frying pan. Deep frying bacon IN bacon grease give SO much more flavor plus, it is uniformly cooked. No uncooked curly tops.

Microwave cooked bacon should not be cooked between paper towels. When you soak up the fat in the paper, you take away the flavor. A Paper towel on top of the bacon is ok to keep the splatter down. Drain on a paper towel after cooking. Microwaving bacon should be for small amounts. When I cook large amounts of bacon, I prefer oven roasting in a flat pan with a small lip lined with tin foil. Fat is flavor! 350 degrees is hot enough and flip the bacon half way through cooking. Move to a paper towel to drain excess fat as soon as it's removed from the oven. After you have done this a few times you get a feel for the correct amount of time. Keep an eye on it. Don't burn it! My method for cooking bacon is for versatility and ease not primarily flavor. Thankfully it always tastes like bacon.

I buy bacon in bulk and cook on wire racked baking sheets in the oven. I slightly undercook the bacon. Then place them on wax paper, bag, and freeze them. The next time you want bacon. Pull out a sheet of wax paper, and using any method you prefer, quickly finish cooking the bacon to your preference.

Tips: When first baking in the oven some pieces may end up being fully cooked. Dispose of them immediately by mouth.

Bonus tip: Strain the bacon juice on the pan through a paper towel into a clean jar. Place in the fridge and use like butter when cooking. Some options are eggs, grilled cheese, burgers, steaks, seafood and rice.

FYI: VERY IMPORTANT FACTOR IN COOKING; "SMOKE POINT"
SMOKE POINT OF BACON: About 325°F. Bacon fat. Bacon fat is the fat rendered when cooking bacon. If you are careful not to burn it you can pour it into a jar and store it in the fridge.

Oven cooking is best. Fry the bacon so it is without done, but the rendered/clarified liquid fat remains and can be stored frozen and used to cook or flavor other foods.

Here's how to do the oven method for bacon that feels like it melts in your mouth. Lay out a cookie sheet (lined with foil) with bacon thawed in the fridge. Set oven for 350, and toss bacon in right away. Set timer for 27 minutes. When the timer goes off, judge the doneness, if more time is needed, turn off the heat but leave in the oven. Check every few minutes. If your timing is right, the bacon will have elements that almost melt in your mouth. Hands down the best way to make it.

My preferred bacon cooking method is low and slow in the oven.
Set the oven as low as it will possibly go, cook for 4-6 hours.
Bacon goes on a wire cooling rack on top of a rimmed baking sheet.
Keeps the bacon from getting greasy, bakes almost perfectly flat and is crispy where the fat renders and chewy where the meat is.
Have to cook large batches to make this method worth it but oh is it worth it..
I believe this is how many hotels and restaurants cook the larger volume of bacon for their meals as well.

The oven mistake I think was going 425...I do mine at 375 and usually takes maybe 20 minutes and comes out perfectly, ovens vary as you well know so I always start checking em at 12 minutes and recheck every 3 minutes and they're usually done within that time frame of 15 to 20 minutes. You have to account for the extra cook time that will occur as a result of the pool of hot oil and hot pan and if you let the bacon rest in the pan until able to touch with finger tips, the combo of slowly cooling off from the room temp air on the one side and the pan still cooking the bacon on the Bacon's pan down side helps crisp them up and you get a great combo of chew and crunch...we call it getting that "Crunchew" on it. 👍😜

Regardless of how you cook bacon, you ALWAYS have to take it away from the heat a little bit before it is done to your liking.
The carry-over heat happens quickly with such a thin cut, but it is always there and the bacon will continue to cook for a little while after it is removed from the heat.

I would also recommend putting it on a rack instead of a stack of paper towels. Paper towels may drain away some of the moisture, but it also keeps a fair amount of the moisture in contact with the meat while it cools and becomes more receptive to reabsorbing it.

COOK BACON IN PAN WITH WATER

Put the bacon strips in the pan with enough water to cover them. Put heat on medium to low and let simmer until water evaporates. Once the water is completely gone continue cooking bacon until crispy (but watch closely as the process is almost finished once the water is gone). The water heats the fat evenly so the bacon cooks evenly, it helps retain the shape of the bacon and the final result is bacon that literally melts in your mouth.
